awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Advancing Biocatalytic Technology for the  Treatment of Emerging Contaminants in Drinking Water
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Zilles
Proposal: 1705804

Emerging drinking water contaminants, such as antibiotics and hormones, affect people's health at extremely low concentrations, making it challenging to remove them and provide safe drinking water. The overarching goal of this work is to protect public health by removing emerging contaminants from drinking water using a new approach: biological catalysts. The engineering benefits and technical feasibility of this approach have been demonstrated, but it is currently too expensive to implement. This project will investigate different strategies for retaining or recovering biological catalysts so they can be reused many times. Achieving biological catalyst reuse has the potential to greatly reduce the costs for public utilities to remove emerging contaminants and provide safe drinking water to consumers.

A biocatalytic (i.e., enzyme-based) approach would allow environmental engineers to draw on the unparalleled specificity and affinity of biological enzymes for the degradation of emerging contaminants under mild conditions. A major barrier to the application of biocatalysts in high volume, low value product industries like drinking water has been their high cost. To reduce costs, biocatalyst reuse has been identified as a key research priority. To address this need, the PIs will investigate pathways for retaining or recovering biocatalysts in a drinking water treatment process. The approach integrates molecular biology, experimental measurements, process modeling, and quantitative sustainable design to provide a comprehensive foundation advancing the development of biocatalytic technologies for drinking water treatment. The hypotheses being tested are that biocatalyst immobilization i) can be accomplished and ii) will allow sufficient rounds of reuse to make biocatalyst acquisition costs financially viable for drinking water utilities. To test these hypotheses, perchlorate-degrading biocatalysts will be immobilized using three different strategies, followed by measurements of their activity and reuse potential in batch and column experiments. The experimental results will be used to develop process models for biocatalytic treatment of perchlorate, and these models will be integrated into a sustainable design framework leveraging life cycle assessment (LCA), life cycle costing (LCC), and techno-economic analysis (TEA). Results from this project will provide a firm foundation for the application of biocatalytic technologies in water treatment by investigating the effects of different immobilization strategies on biocatalyst activity and longevity, integrating that understanding into process-scale models, and applying quantitative sustainable design to evaluate the economic and environmental tradeoffs associated with different immobilization strategies and process designs. Overall, this work will contribute to safe drinking water by developing a biocatalytic treatment technology that specifically targets perchlorate and chlorite. More generally, this work could transform our approach to emerging contaminants by providing proof of concept for the overall feasibility of biocatalytic approaches in water treatment, providing a vast new toolbox to environmental engineers and facilitating safe water reuse. Interdisciplinary education of undergraduate and graduate students is embedded in the project, and specific educational objectives are designed to increase awareness of emerging contaminants and biological treatment processes, recruit a diverse student population, and improve the communication skills of undergraduate and graduate engineering students.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this work is to protect public health by developing methods for the targeted degradation of emerging contaminants in drinking water. Specifically, this research investigated the potential of biocatalysis, in which enzymes break down contaminants.  Perchlorate and chlorite were used as model contaminants. Perchlorate causes iodide deficiency, with particularly severe consequences for fetuses and young children. Chlorite can cause oxidative damage and interferes with the delivery of oxygen throughout the body. Enzymes from perchlorate-reducing bacteria are able to degrade perchlorate and chlorite and have been proposed for biocatalytic treatment of drinking water. However, for biocatalysis to be cost-effective at the scale required for drinking water treatment, it is essential that the biocatalysts can be reused. This project included i) experiments to investigate options for reusing the biocatalysts and ii) modeling and techno-economic analysis to investigate the feasibility and implications of various options. Developing biocatalysts for water treatment provides a new toolbox for environmental engineers to remove emerging contaminants, improving our ability to supply safe drinking water, protect the environment, and facilitate water reuse.

Investigate options for biocatalyst reuse: The chlorite-degrading biocatalyst was successfully attached to resin beads and maintained high activity. Columns containing different loadings of the biocatalyst were tested with a variety of chlorite concentrations to investigate the treatment rate and the longevity of the biocatalyst. Longevity was also tested with dechlorinated tap water to ensure that any effects of other constituents in the water were accounted for. Chlorite was successfully removed in continuous column experiments under a variety of conditions. Columns with lower chlorite loading rates lasted longer, with one column removing chlorite for up to 35 days. Biocatalyst loading was deliberately low, below 2% of column capacity, to allow more experiments to be completed, so these are conservative estimates of potential activity. Importantly, experiments with dechlorinated tap water performed similarly to those conducted with nanopure water. Taken together, these experiments support the potential of this biocatalytic treatment process. These data also provided necessary treatment rates and estimates of biocatalyst longevity for realistic modeling.

Some current ion exchange technologies for perchlorate removal produce a waste brine contaminated with perchlorate, which is often diluted and released to the environment. Considering the possibility of treating this brine with biocatalysis, we also investigated the impact of high salt. Brine did lower the activity of the biocatalysts, but sufficient activity was retained that the possibility of a hybrid process integrating ion exchange, resin regeneration with brine, and biocatalytic brine detoxification and regeneration is worthy of further investigation.

Modeling costs and impacts of biocatalytic treatment: Based on the experimental results, equations representing the activity of the attached biocatalyst were developed. These activity equations were incorporated into multiple models of possible treatment processes, with and without biocatalyst reuse, to investigate the costs and impacts of the biocatalytic approach. The previously proposed technology development target of 1,000 bed volumes of reuse has been surpassed, based on column performance in the laboratory. Modeling suggests that more than 100,000 bed volumes can be treated. Techno-economic analysis shows that the biocatalyst reuse results in substantially reduced treatment costs.

Education and dissemination: This project contributed to the education and professional development of two M.S. students, two Ph.D. students, and two postdocs. In addition to dissemination to scientists through talks and conference presentations, members of the project participated in outreach to elementary, middle school, and high school students. To increase awareness of emerging contaminants and technologies for treating them among undergraduate and graduate students, a class session on perchlorate removal was added to CEE 493 Sustainable Design of Engineering Technologies.
